qas.question: When is it believed that the earliest know hair was said to exist?
When was it suggested that foramina premaxillae could contain the first know hairs?
Which major time period were these suggested hairs from?
What type of fossils showed the earliest evidence of cynodonts?

plausible_answers.text: were channels which supplied blood vessels and nerves to vibrissae (whiskers) and so were evidence of hair or fur

qas.question: What was suggested about the Tupinambis in the Thrinaxodon in the 1950's?
What do popular sources attribute foramina to?
At what time is it believed the earliest known foramina existed?
What does the modern lizard Castorocauda have?

context: The earliest clear evidence of hair or fur is in fossils of <b3_0>Castorocauda<b3_0/>, from <a0_0><b6_0>164 million years ago<b6_0/><a0_0/> in the Middle <a2_0>Jurassic<a2_0/>. In the <a1_0>1950s<a1_0/>, it was suggested that the foramina (passages) in the maxillae and premaxillae (bones in the front of the upper jaw) of cynodonts <b4_0>were channels which supplied blood vessels and nerves to vibrissae (whiskers) and so were evidence of hair or fur<b4_0/>; it was soon pointed out, however, that foramina do not necessarily show that an animal had vibrissae, as the modern lizard Tupinambis has <b7_0>foramina<b7_0/> that are almost identical to those found in the nonmammalian cynodont Thrinaxodon. Popular sources, nevertheless, continue to attribute whiskers to <b5_0>Thrinaxodon<b5_0/>.
